Company: ExxonMobil Pipeline Company and Mobil Pipe Line Company
Description: ExxonMobil Pipeline Company and Mobil Pipe Line Company agreed to pay civil penalties, fund an environmental project and implement corrective measures to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Water Act and state environmental laws stemming from a 2013 crude oil spill from the Pegasus Pipeline in Mayflower, Arkansas. Under a consent decree lodged in federal court, ExxonMobil was required to pay $3.19 million in federal civil penalties and take steps to address pipeline safety issues and oil spill response capability.  In addition, ExxonMobil was obliged to pay $1 million in state civil penalties, $600,000 for a project to improve water quality at Lake Conway, and $280,000 to the Arkansas Attorney Generals Office for the state's litigation costs.

Description: Mobil Natural Gas Inc., Mobil Exploration & Producing U.S. Inc. and their affiliates agreed to pay the United States $32.2 million to resolve claims that they violated the False Claims Act by knowingly underpaying royalties owed on natural gas produced from federal and American Indian leases. The Mobil companies are alleged to have systematically under reported the value of natural gas taken from the leases from March 1, 1988, to Nov. 30, 1999, and, consequently, paid less royalties than owed to the United States and various American Indian tribes.

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Justice announced a settlement with XTO Energy Inc., a subsidiary of Exxon Mobil Corporation, to resolve an alleged violation of the Clean Water Act (CWA) related to the discharge of wastewater from XTO's Penn Township, Lycoming County, Pa. facility used for the storage of wastewater generated by natural gas exploration, commonly known as fracking, and production. The federal settlement requires that XTO pay a penalty of $100,000 to the United States and spend a federal government-estimated $20 million on a comprehensive plan to improve wastewater management practices to recycle, properly dispose of, and prevent spills of wastewater generated from natural gas exploration and production activities in Pennsylvania and West Virginia.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced that XTO Energy Inc. (XTO), a subsidiary of ExxonMobil and the nation's largest holder of natural gas reserves, will spend an estimated $3 million to restore eight sites damaged by unauthorized discharges of fill material into streams and wetlands in connection with hydraulic fracturing operations. XTO also agreed to implement a comprehensive plan to comply with federal and state water protection laws at the company's oil and gas extraction facilities in West Virginia that use horizontal drilling methods. The company was required to pay a civil penalty of $2.3 million for violations of Section 404 of the Clean Water Act and West Virginia law.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: Exxon Mobil agreed to pay a fine of $2.5 million and spend $300 million on air pollution controls to resolve allegations that it violated the Clean Air Act by failing to properly operate and monitor industrial flares at its petrochemical facilities.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Clean Water Act violation in connection with a spill of approximately 15,000 gallons of diesel oil into the Mystic River from ExxonMobil's oil terminal in Everett, Mass.

Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Private Litigation Case Title: Soheil Meili v. Exxon Mobil Corporation et al

Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue

Description: The U.S. Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with ExxonMobil Oil Corporation to resolve federal Clean Air Act claims arising from a 2013 fire at the company's oil refinery in Beaumont, Texas that killed two employees and injured ten others.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Exxon Mobil agreed to pay $10,75 million for oil spill cleanup and petroleum contamination removal costs at eight locations across the state.

ExxonMobil agreed to pay $18.4 million -- $8.7 million in civil penalties and $9.7 million for environmental projects -- to Illinois, Louisiana and Montana as well as the federal government to settle Clean Air Act violations at seven petroleum refineries. This was part of a larger $589 million settlement announced by the U.S. Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-exxonmobil-2
To resolve multistate litigation ExxonMobil agreed to pay to pay $100,000 and implement major new policies to reduce the sale of tobacco products to minors.
ExxonMobil agreed to pay $1 million in civil penalties, $600,000 for environmental projects, and $280,000 in to settle allegations relating to a 2013 pipeline accident.

ExxonMobil and Petco agreed to pay a total of $2,050,000 for the cleanup of 92 abandoned oilwells the companies once owned in Michigan. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume each paid half.

A state court jury reached a $236 million verdict against ExxonMobil for contaminating groundwater with the gasoline additive MTBE. The company appealed but the verdict was upheld by the New Hampshire Supreme Court in 2016: https://www.doj.nh.gov/news/2016/20160516-exxonmobile-verdict.htm

A New Jersey Superior Court Judge approved a $225 million settlement between the State and ExxonMobil to resolve liability for damage to the environment and injury to natural resources caused by contamination from the corporation's refinery operations in Bayonne and Linden, as well as other facilities and service stations in the state.

ExxonMobil agreed to pay $2.9 million civil penalty and $200,000 to an environmental project in settlement of allegations its bulk gasoline terminals in Everett and Springfield violated the state's air pollution laws.
ExxonMobil Corp. agreed to pay New Mexico $400,000 in royalties on carbon dioxide pumped from state lands and agreed to change the way it calculated royalties.
Info Source: State Land Office reaches settlement in carbon dioxide payments, Associated Press, May 21, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: ExxonMobil Corporation agreed to pay $25 million and perform a full clean up of its long-running oil spill Greenpoint, Brooklyn as well as any related environmental contamination.

The New York Attorney General announced a settlement with Exxon-Mobil Corporation and Arrow Petroleum Inc. in which the state will be reimbursed $3.8 million for the cost of cleaning up fuel spills at gasoline stations in Farmingdale.

ExxonMobil agreed to repay $2 million it received from the state to clean up gasoline spills at service stations after the state learned that the company had also been reimbursed by private insurance for the work.

ExxonMobil Oil Corp. agreed to pay up to $70,000 in costs in settlement of allegations that a procedural failure at its refinery caused an oil mixture to fall onto homes and farms within a four-mile radius.

ExxonMobil Oil Corp. agreed to pay $110,000 to local government, $150,000 to the Illinois Environmental Protection Trust Fund, and $21,846 to the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency for costs, in settlement of alleged air pollution violations at its Joliet refinery.

ExxonMobil agreed to pay $175,000 in settlement of allegations it violated the Clean Air Acit by operating gasoline pumps with inadequate or damaged vapor recovery equipment, allowing excessive amounts of fuel vapor to be emitted.

ExxonMobil agreed to pay $12 million to the federal government and the state of Montana in settlement of allegations and oil spill into the Yellowstone River from its Silvertip Pipeline caused natural resource damages.
Agency: Interior Department referral to the Justice Department

Description: ExxonMobil agreed to pay $12 million to the federal government and the state of Montana in settlement of allegations and oil spill into the Yellowstone River from its Silvertip Pipeline caused natural resource damages. The settlement was also announced by the U.S. Justice Department: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/public-and-environment-benefit-proposed-12-million-settlement-exxonmobil-natural-resource
The settlement resolved allegations that XTO Energy illegally discharged toxic waste from a Marcellus Shale gas well site in Penn Township, Lycoming County.
Info Source: XTO Energy to Pay $400K, Enter Disposition Program as Part of Settlement with Office of Attorney General, US State News, August 4, 2016 (via Nexis).

Description: Shell, Mobil, Texaco and Kinder Morgan agreed to pay a total of $700,000 in settlement of allegations that two sites the companies used in San Diego for fuel storage or pipelines had contaminated soil and groundwater. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here was assume the total was divided equally among them.

Private Litigation Case Title: Michelle Kendig et al v. Exxonmobil Oil Corp. et al

MOBIL CHEM CO BEAUMONT OLEFINS AROMATICS

Description: ExxonMobil agreed to pay a $1.3 million penalty and fund supplemental environmental projects at a cost of $1.1 million in settlement of allegations it failed to comply with its air quality permit at its Shute Creek Plant.

The Justice Department, the EPA and the State of Illinois announced an amendment to the 2005 Clean Air Act consent decree signed with ExxonMobil Oil Corporation to resolve violations at its petroleum refinery in Joliet. Under the amendment, ExxonMobil will pay $1,515,463 in penalties -- $1,086,640 to the federal government and $428,823 to the State of Illinois. The amendment also includes an estimated $10 million of improvements to reduce air emissions from the facility.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
West Virginia Department of Environmental Protection

Description: As part of multidistrict litigation over the contamination of groundwater with the gasoline additive MTBE, Exxon Mobil agreed to pay $25 million to Puerto Rico.
Private Litigation Case Title: Commonwealth of Puerto Rico v. Shell Oil Company

Description: Exxon Mobil agreed to pay $7 million to settle a class action brought by residents of Pascoag, Rhode Island and the Rhode Island Water District as a result of the contamination of their well water supply by the gasoline additive MTBE.

On March 24, 1989 Exxon's supertanker Valdez went aground off the coast of Alaska and spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into the Prince William Sound, polluting more than 700 miles of shoreline. After several years of legal maneuvering, in September 1994 a federal jury ordered Exxon to pay $5 billion in punitive damages. Exxon delayed as long as possible in paying any of the damages by pursuing a protracted appeals process. In 2001 it got a federal appeals court to rule that the punitive damage award was excessive, prompting the judge in the case to reduce the amount to $4 billion. The case finally reached reached the U.S. Supreme Court, which in 2008 slashed the punitive damage award to $507.5 million.

Exxon Mobil agreed to pay $8.5 million to a group of New Orleans residents to resolve claims relating to contamination caused by offshore pipe cleaning near the Harvey Canal. The settlement amount was cited in a subsequent federal lawsuit in which additional plaintiffs sought damages.

Shell, Exxon Mobil and ChevronTexaco agreed to pay a total of $92.5 million to resolve a lawsuit brought by Santa Monica alleging that they contaminated the city's water supplies with the gasoline additive MTBE. It was not disclosed how much each company would pay; here we assume they each paid one-third of the total. The companies also agreed to pay for a water treatment plant expected to cost several hundred million dollars.
Exxon agreed to pay $12 million to settle litigation related to MTBE contamination of the water supply in South Lake Tahoe, California.
Private Litigation Case Title: SO. TAHOE PUBLIC VS. ATLANTIC RICHFIELD
